{"output":"[build-system]
requires = ["hatchling"]
build-backend = "hatchling.build"

[project]
name = "cpolar-connect"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Easy-to-use CLI tool for cpolar tunnel management and SSH connections"
authors = [
    {name = "Hoper_J", email = "hoper.hw@gmail.com"},
]
readme = "README.md"
license = {file = "LICENSE"}
requires-python = ">=3.9"
keywords = ["cpolar", "tunnel", "ssh", "automation", "cli"]
classifiers = [
    "Development Status :: 4 - Beta",
    "Environment :: Console",
    "Intended Audience :: Developers",
    "License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License",
    "Operating System :: OS Independent",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.9",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.10",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.11",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.12",
    "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.13",
    "Topic :: System :: Networking",
    "Topic :: Utilities",
]
dependencies = [
    "click>=8.0.0",
    "requests>=2.28.0",
    "beautifulsoup4>=4.11.0",
    "paramiko>=2.11.0",
    "keyring>=24.0.0",
    "rich>=13.0.0",
    "pydantic>=2.0.0",
]

[project.optional-dependencies]
dev = [
    "pytest>=7.0.0",
    "pytest-cov>=4.0.0",
    "black>=23.0.0",
    "isort>=5.12.0",
    "mypy>=1.0.0",
    "pre-commit>=3.0.0",
]

[project.urls]
Homepage = "https://github.com/Hoper-J/cpolar-connect"
Repository = "https://github.com/Hoper-J/cpolar-connect.git"
Issues = "https://github.com/Hoper-J/cpolar-connect/issues"

[project.scripts]
cpolar-connect = "cpolar_connect.cli:main"

[tool.hatch.build.targets.sdist]
include = [
    "/src",
    "/tests",
    "/README.md",
    "/LICENSE",
]

[tool.hatch.build.targets.wheel]
packages = ["src/cpolar_connect"]

[tool.black]
line-length = 88
target-version = ['py39']

[tool.isort]
profile = "black"
line_length = 88

[tool.mypy]
python_version = "3.9"
warn_return_any = true
warn_unused_configs = true
disallow_untyped_defs = true

[tool.pytest.ini_options]
testpaths = ["tests"]
python_files = ["test_*.py"]
addopts = "--cov=cpolar_connect --cov-report=html --cov-report=term-missing"
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

{"output":"# Cpolar Connect
[![PyPI version](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/cpolar-connect.svg)](https://pypi.org/project/cpolar-connect/) [![Python](https://img.shields.io/pypi/pyversions/cpolar-connect.svg)](https://pypi.org/project/cpolar-connect/) [![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](LICENSE) 中文 | [English](./README_en.md) **🚀 自动化管理 cpolar 内网穿透连接的命令行工具**
## ✨ 为什么需要这个工具？ cpolar 免费版的隧道地址会时不时重置，每次都需要： 1. 登录 cpolar 网站查看新地址 2. 手动更新 SSH 配置 3. 记住新的端口号 **Cpolar Connect 会解决这些问题。** ## 🎯 主要特性 - 🔄 **自动更新**: 自动获取最新的 cpolar 隧道地址 - 🔐 **安全存储**: 密码加密保存，支持系统密钥环 - 🌏 **双语支持**: 中英文界面智能切换 - ⚡ **一键连接**: 无需记忆地址和端口 - 🔑 **SSH 密钥**: 自动配置免密登录 - 📦 **简单安装**: 一行命令即可使用 ## 📦 安装方法 ### 方式一：使用 uv（推荐，最快） 首先安装 uv： **Linux/macOS:** ```bash # 使用官方安装脚本 curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh # 或使用 pip pip install uv ``` **Windows:** ```powershell # 使用 PowerShell powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex" # 或使用 pip pip install uv ``` 然后运行 cpolar-connect： ```bash # 直接运行（无需安装） uvx cpolar-connect # 或安装到系统 uv tool install cpolar-connect ``` ### 方式二：使用 pipx（独立环境） ```bash # 安装 pipx install cpolar-connect # 升级 pipx upgrade cpolar-connect ``` ### 方式三：使用 pip ```bash pip install cpolar-connect ``` ## 🚀 快速开始 ### 服务器端配置 > 服务器需要先安装并运行 cpolar，详见 [服务器配置指南](docs/SERVER_SETUP.md) 快速配置（Linux）： ```bash # 1. 安装 cpolar curl -L https://www.cpolar.com/static/downloads/install-release-cpolar.sh | sudo bash # 2. 配置认证（需要先注册 cpolar 账号） cpolar authtoken YOUR_TOKEN # 3. 设置开机自启 sudo systemctl enable cpolar sudo systemctl start cpolar # 4. 查看用户名（客户端配置需要） whoami ``` ### 客户端配置 #### 1️⃣ 初始化配置 ```bash cpolar-connect init ``` 根据提示输入： - 📧 cpolar 用户名（邮箱） - 👤 服务器用户名（上面 whoami 的结果） - 🔌 要转发的端口（默认 8888,6666） - 🔑 是否保存密码（推荐） #### 2️⃣ 连接服务器 ```bash # 直接连接 cpolar-connect # 或使用环境变量提供密码 CPOLAR_PASSWORD=your_password cpolar-connect ``` **就这么简单！** 工具会自动： - ✅ 登录 cpolar 获取最新地址 - ✅ 生成 SSH 密钥（首次） - ✅ 配置免密登录 - ✅ 建立连接并转发端口 ## ⚙️ 配置管理 ### 查看配置 ```bash cpolar-connect config show ``` ### 修改配置 ```bash # 修改服务器用户 cpolar-connect config set server.user ubuntu # 修改端口 cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8080,3000 # 直接编辑配置文件 cpolar-connect config edit ``` ### 切换语言 ```bash # 中文 cpolar-connect language zh # English cpolar-connect language en ``` ## 🔒 密码管理 ### 选项 1：环境变量（推荐） ```bash export CPOLAR_PASSWORD=your_password cpolar-connect ``` **优点**：不需要系统权限，不会触发 macOS 钥匙串权限提示。 ### 选项 2：系统密钥环（最安全） 初始化时选择保存密码，将安全存储在系统密钥环中。 > **macOS 用户注意**：首次访问钥匙串时，系统会提示授权。请选择“始终允许”以避免重复提示。 ### 选项 3：每次输入 不保存密码，每次连接时输入。 ## 📚 使用场景 ### Jupyter Notebook ```bash # 配置端口 8888 cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8888 # 连接后本地访问 # http://localhost:8888 ``` ### 多端口转发 ```bash # 配置多个端口 cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8888,6006,3000 # 连接后： # localhost:8888 -> 服务器:8888 (Jupyter) # localhost:6006 -> 服务器:6006 (TensorBoard) # localhost:3000 -> 服务器:3000 (Web App) ``` ","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

{"output":" ### SSH 别名快速连接 ```bash # 连接成功后，可使用别名 ssh cpolar-server ``` ## 📁 文件位置 - 配置文件：`~/.cpolar_connect/config.json` - SSH 密钥：`~/.ssh/id_rsa_cpolar` - 日志文件：`~/.cpolar_connect/logs/cpolar.log` ## 🏥 诊断工具 遇到问题时，使用内置诊断工具快速定位： ```bash cpolar-connect doctor ``` 这会检查： - ✅ 配置文件完整性 - ✅ 网络连接状态 - ✅ Cpolar 认证 - ✅ SSH 密钥和配置 - ✅ 活动隧道状态 输出示例： ``` 🏥 诊断结果 ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ 检查项 ┃ 状态 ┃ 详情 ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ 配置文件 │ ✅ OK │ 配置有效 │ │ 网络连接 │ ✅ OK │ 网络连接正常 │ │ Cpolar 认证 │ ✅ OK │ 成功认证 cpolar │ │ 隧道状态 │ ⚠️ WARN │ 没有活动隧道 │ └────────────────┴────────┴──────────────────┘ ``` ## ❓ 常见问题 ### 无法连接？ 1. 运行诊断：`cpolar-connect doctor` 2. 确认服务器 cpolar 正在运行：`sudo systemctl status cpolar` 3. 确认用户名密码正确 4. 查看详细日志：`CPOLAR_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG cpolar-connect` ### 如何卸载？ ```bash # uv uv tool uninstall cpolar-connect # pipx pipx uninstall cpolar-connect # pip pip uninstall cpolar-connect ``` ### 支持哪些系统？ - ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, CentOS, Debian...) - ✅ macOS - ❓ Windows ## 🤝 贡献 欢迎提交 Issue 和 Pull Request！ ## 📄 许可证 MIT License - 详见 [LICENSE](LICENSE) ## 🔗 相关链接 - [cpolar 官网](https://www.cpolar.com) - [服务器配置指南](docs/SERVER_SETUP.md) - [问题反馈](https://github.com/Hoper-J/cpolar-connect/issues) ---
感谢你的STAR🌟，希望这一切对你有所帮助。

{"output":"# Cpolar Connect
[![PyPI version](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/cpolar-connect.svg)](https://pypi.org/project/cpolar-connect/) [![Python](https://img.shields.io/pypi/pyversions/cpolar-connect.svg)](https://pypi.org/project/cpolar-connect/) [![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](LICENSE) [中文](./README.md) | English **🚀 A command-line tool for automating cpolar tunnel management and SSH connections**
## ✨ Why This Tool? The free version of cpolar resets tunnel addresses periodically, requiring you to: 1. Log in to the cpolar website to check the new address 2. Manually update SSH configuration 3. Remember the new port number **Cpolar Connect solves all these problems with one command!** ## 🎯 Key Features - 🔄 **Auto-update**: Automatically fetch the latest cpolar tunnel address - 🔐 **Secure Storage**: Encrypted password storage with system keyring - 🌏 **Bilingual Support**: Smart switching between Chinese and English interfaces - ⚡ **One-click Connection**: No need to remember addresses and ports - 🔑 **SSH Keys**: Automatic configuration for passwordless login - 📦 **Simple Installation**: Ready to use with one command ## 📦 Installation ### Method 1: Using uv (Recommended, Fastest) First install uv: **Linux/macOS:** ```bash # Using official installer curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh # Or using pip pip install uv ``` **Windows:** ```powershell # Using PowerShell powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex" # Or using pip pip install uv ``` Then run cpolar-connect: ```bash # Run directly (no installation needed) uvx cpolar-connect # Or install to system uv tool install cpolar-connect ``` ### Method 2: Using pipx (Isolated Environment) ```bash # Install pipx install cpolar-connect # Upgrade pipx upgrade cpolar-connect ``` ### Method 3: Using pip ```bash pip install cpolar-connect ``` ## 🚀 Quick Start ### Server Configuration > Server needs cpolar installed and running. See [Server Setup Guide](docs/SERVER_SETUP_en.md) Quick setup (Linux): ```bash # 1. Install cpolar curl -L https://www.cpolar.com/static/downloads/install-release-cpolar.sh | sudo bash # 2. Configure authentication (register cpolar account first) cpolar authtoken YOUR_TOKEN # 3. Enable auto-start sudo systemctl enable cpolar sudo systemctl start cpolar # 4. Check username (needed for client configuration) whoami ``` ### Client Configuration #### 1️⃣ Initialize Configuration ```bash cpolar-connect init ``` Enter when prompted: - 📧 Cpolar username (email) - 👤 Server username (from `whoami` above) - 🔌 Ports to forward (default 8888,6666) - 🔑 Store password (recommended) #### 2️⃣ Connect to Server ```bash # Direct connection cpolar-connect # Or provide password via environment variable CPOLAR_PASSWORD=your_password cpolar-connect ``` **That's it!** The tool will automatically: - ✅ Log in to cpolar to get the latest address - ✅ Generate SSH keys (first time) - ✅ Configure passwordless login - ✅ Establish connection and forward ports ## ⚙️ Configuration Management ### View Configuration ```bash cpolar-connect config show ``` ### Modify Configuration ```bash # Change server user cpolar-connect config set server.user ubuntu # Change ports cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8080,3000 # Edit config file directly cpolar-connect config edit ``` ### Switch Language ```bash # Chinese cpolar-connect language zh # English cpolar-connect language en ``` ## 🔒 Password Management ### Option 1: Environment Variable (Recommended) ```bash export CPOLAR_PASSWORD=your_password cpolar-connect ``` **Advantage**: No system permissions required, won't trigger macOS keychain permission prompts. ### Option 2: System Keyring (Most Secure) Choose to save password during initialization for secure storage in the system keyring. > **macOS Users Note**: When accessing the keychain for the first time, the system will prompt for authorization. Please select "Always Allow" to avoid repeated prompts. ### Option 3: Enter Each Time Don't save password and enter it each time you connect. ## 📚 Use Cases ### Jupyter Notebook ```bash # Configure port 8888 cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8888 # Access locally after connection # http://localhost:8888 ``` ### Multiple Port Forwarding ```bash # Configure multiple ports cpolar-connect config set server.ports 8888,6006,3000 # After connection: # localhost:8888 -> server:8888 (Jupyter) # localhost:6006 -> server:6006 (TensorBoard) # localhost:3000 -> server:3000 (Web App) ``` ### SSH Alias Quick Connect ```bash # After successful connection, use alias ssh cpolar-server ``` ## 📁 File Locations - Configuration: `~/.cpolar_connect/config.json` - SSH Key: `~/.ssh/id_rsa_cpolar` - Log File: `~/.cpolar_connect/logs/cpolar.log` ## 🏥 Diagnostic Tool When encountering issues, use the built-in diagnostic tool for quick troubleshooting: ```bash cpolar-connect doctor ``` ","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

{"output":" This checks: - ✅ Configuration file integrity - ✅ Network connection status - ✅ Cpolar authentication - ✅ SSH keys and configuration - ✅ Active tunnel status Example output: ``` 🏥 Diagnosis Results ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Check Item ┃ Status ┃ Details ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ Configuration │ ✅ OK │ Config valid │ │ Network │ ✅ OK │ Connection good │ │ Cpolar Auth │ ✅ OK │ Auth successful │ │ Tunnel Status │ ⚠️ WARN │ No active tunnel │ └────────────────┴────────┴──────────────────┘ ``` ## ❓ FAQ ### Can't connect? 1. Run diagnostics: `cpolar-connect doctor` 2. Check cpolar is running on server: `sudo systemctl status cpolar` 3. Verify username and password are correct 4. View detailed logs: `CPOLAR_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG cpolar-connect` ### How to uninstall? ```bash # uv uv tool uninstall cpolar-connect # pipx pipx uninstall cpolar-connect # pip pip uninstall cpolar-connect ``` ### Which systems are supported? - ✅ Linux (Ubuntu, CentOS, Debian...) - ✅ macOS - ❓ Windows ## 🤝 Contributing Issues and Pull Requests are welcome! ## 📄 License MIT License - See [LICENSE](LICENSE) ## 🔗 Links - [cpolar Official Website](https://www.cpolar.com) - [Server Setup Guide](docs/SERVER_SETUP_en.md) - [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/Hoper-J/cpolar-connect/issues) ---

# 服务器配置指南

本指南将帮助您在服务器上配置 cpolar 内网穿透服务，用于 SSH 远程连接。

## 📋 前置要求

- 一台运行 Linux/Windows/macOS 的服务器
- cpolar 账号（免费版即可）
- SSH 服务已启动

## 🐧 Linux 服务器配置

### 1. 安装 cpolar

国内用户：
```bash
curl -L https://www.cpolar.com/static/downloads/install-release-cpolar.sh | sudo bash
```

国外用户：
```bash
curl -sL https://git.io/cpolar | sudo bash
```

### 2. Token 认证

1. 访问 cpolar：https://dashboard.cpolar.com/signup 注册账号（无需验证邮箱和手机号）

   ![登录](https://i-blog.csdnimg.cn/blog_migrate/5525126a4890c9305b47a25620a3569e.png)

2. 登录后访问：https://dashboard.cpolar.com/auth 查看您的认证 token

## ❓ Frequently Asked Questions

### Q: What are the limitations of cpolar free version?

- Tunnel addresses change periodically (reset every 24 hours)
- This is exactly the problem cpolar-connect solves - automatically fetching the latest address

### Q: How to ensure SSH security?

1. Use strong passwords
2. cpolar-connect will automatically configure SSH key authentication
3. Consider changing the default SSH port (requires corresponding cpolar configuration change)

### Q: Do I need manual operations after server restart?

No. After configuring systemctl auto-start, the cpolar service will start automatically when the server restarts.

import logging
import requests
from typing import Optional, Tuple
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from rich.console import Console

from .config import ConfigManager
from .exceptions import AuthenticationError, NetworkError
from .i18n import _

console = Console()
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


class CpolarAuth:
    """Handle cpolar authentication"""
    
    def __init__(self, config_manager: ConfigManager):
        """Initialize authentication with config manager"""
        self.config_manager = config_manager
        self.config = config_manager.get_config()
        self.session = requests.Session()
        self.session.headers.update({
            'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36'
        })
        self.base_url = self.config.base_url
        self.login_url = f"{self.base_url}/login"
        self.status_url = f"{self.base_url}/status"
        self.authenticated = False
    
    def get_csrf_token(self) -> str:
        """Get CSRF token from login page"""
        try:
            response = self.session.get(self.login_url, timeout=10)
            response.raise_for_status()
            
            soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
            csrf_input = soup.find("input", {"name": "csrf_token"})
            
            if not csrf_input:
                # Try alternative methods
                # Sometimes the token might be in meta tag
                meta_csrf = soup.find("meta", {"name": "csrf-token"})
                if meta_csrf:
                    return meta_csrf.get("content", "")
                
                logger.error("CSRF token not found in login page")
                raise AuthenticationError(_('error.csrf_token_not_found'))
            
            csrf_token = csrf_input.get("value", "")
            if not csrf_token:
                raise AuthenticationError(_('error.csrf_token_empty'))
            
            logger.debug("Successfully obtained CSRF token")
            return csrf_token
            
        except requests.RequestException as e:
            logger.error(f"Network error while getting login page: {e}")
            raise NetworkError(_('error.network', error=e))
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error getting CSRF token: {e}")
            raise AuthenticationError(_('error.auth', error=e))
    
    def login(self, username: Optional[str] = None, password: Optional[str] = None) -> requests.Session:
        """
        Login to cpolar and return authenticated session
        
        Args:
            username: Override config username if provided
            password: Override config password if provided
            
        Returns:
            Authenticated requests.Session object
        """
        # Get credentials
        if not username:
            username = self.config.username
        
        if not password:
            password = self.config_manager.get_password(username)
            if not password:
                raise AuthenticationError(_('auth.password_required'))
        
        try:
            # Step 1: Get CSRF token
            console.print(f"[dim]{_('auth.csrf_token')}[/dim]")
            csrf_token = self.get_csrf_token()
            
            # Step 2: Submit login form
            console.print(f"[dim]{_('auth.logging_in', username=username)}[/dim]")
            
            # Try different field names based on what cpolar might expect
            login_data = {
                'login': username,  # or could be 'username' or 'email'
                'password': password,
                'csrf_token': csrf_token
            }
            
            # Debug: log the form fields we're sending (without password)
            logger.debug(f"Login form fields: {list(login_data.keys())}")
            logger.debug(f"Login URL: {self.login_url}")
            
            response = self.session.post(
                self.login_url, 
                data=login_data,
                timeout=10,
                allow_redirects=False  # Handle redirects manually
            )
            
            # Check for redirect (successful login typically redirects)
            if response.status_code in [302, 303]:
                redirect_url = response.headers.get('Location', '')
                logger.debug(f"Login redirected to: {redirect_url}")
                
                # Follow the redirect
                response = self.session.get(
                    redirect_url if redirect_url.startswith('http') else f"{self.base_url}{redirect_url}",
                    timeout=10
                )
                response.raise_for_status()
            else:
                response.raise_for_status()
            
            # Step 3: Verify login success
[... omitted 15 of 271 lines ...]

        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Unexpected error during login: {e}")
            raise AuthenticationError(_('error.auth', error=e))
    
    def _verify_authentication(self, response: requests.Response) -> bool:
        """
        Verify that authentication was successful
        
        Args:
            response: Response from login POST request
            
        Returns:
            True if authentication successful, False otherwise
        """
        response_text = response.text.lower()
        
        # Check for success indicators
        success_indicators = [
            'logout',
            'status',
            'dashboard',
            'tunnel',
            '隧道',  # Chinese for tunnel
            'get-started'  # Cpolar redirect page after login
        ]
        
        # Check for failure indicators (be more specific)
        failure_indicators = [
            'login failed',
            'invalid credentials',
            'incorrect password',
            'authentication failed',
            '登录失败',  # Chinese for login failed
            '密码错误'   # Chinese for wrong password
        ]
        
        # If we find failure indicators, authentication failed
        for indicator in failure_indicators:
            if indicator in response_text:
                logger.debug(f"Found failure indicator: {indicator}")
                return False
        
        # If we find success indicators, authentication succeeded
        for indicator in success_indicators:
            if indicator in response_text:
                logger.debug(f"Found success indicator: {indicator}")
                return True
        
        # Check if we're still on login page
        if '/login' in response.url:
            logger.debug("Still on login page after POST")
            return False
        
        # If redirected to status, dashboard, or get-started, consider it success  
        if any(path in response.url for path in ['/status', '/dashboard', '/get-started']):
            logger.debug(f"Redirected to {response.url}")
            return True
        
        # Default to checking for specific text
        return 'logout' in response_text or 'status' in response_text
    
    def logout(self) -> None:
        """Logout from cpolar"""
        if not self.authenticated:
            return
        
        try:
            logout_url = f"{self.base_url}/logout"
            self.session.get(logout_url, timeout=5)
            self.authenticated = False
            logger.info("Logged out from cpolar")
        except Exception as e:
            # Logout errors are not critical
            logger.debug(f"Error during logout: {e}")
    
    def test_connection(self) -> bool:
        """Test connection to cpolar"""
        try:
            response = self.session.get(self.base_url, timeout=10)
            return response.status_code == 200
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Connection test failed: {e}")
            return False
    
    def is_authenticated(self) -> bool:
        """Check if currently authenticated"""
        if not self.authenticated:
            return False
        
        # Try to access status page to verify session is still valid
        try:
            response = self.session.get(self.status_url, timeout=10, allow_redirects=True)
            
            # Check if redirected to login page
            if '/login' in response.url.lower():
                self.authenticated = False
                return False
            
            # Check for authentication indicators in response
            response_text = response.text.lower()
            if response.status_code == 200:
                # Look for indicators we're logged in
                if any(indicator in response_text for indicator in ['logout', 'status', 'tunnel', '隧道']):
                    return True
                # If we see login form elements, we're not authenticated
                if any(indicator in response_text for indicator in ['password', 'login', 'sign in']):
                    self.authenticated = False
                    return False
            
            return response.status_code == 200
        except Exception as e:
            logger.debug(f"Authentication check failed: {e}")
            self.authenticated = False
            return False
    
    def get_session(self) -> requests.Session:
        """Get the current session, login if necessary"""
        if not self.is_authenticated():
            self.login()
        return self.session
    
    def __enter__(self):
        """Context manager entry - login"""
        return self.get_session()
    
    def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb):
        """Context manager exit - logout"""
        self.logout()","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

import re

class TunnelInfo:
    """Data class for tunnel information"""
    
    def __init__(self, url: str, hostname: str, port: int, name: str = "ssh"):
        self.url = url  # Full URL like tcp://xxx:port
        self.hostname = hostname
        self.port = port
        self.name = name
        self.active = True
    
    def __str__(self):
        return f"Tunnel(name={self.name}, url={self.url}, host={self.hostname}, port={self.port})"
    
    def to_dict(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Convert to dictionary"""
        return {
            'url': self.url,
            'hostname': self.hostname,
            'port': self.port,
            'name': self.name,
            'active': self.active
        }


class TunnelManager:
    """Manage cpolar tunnel information"""
    
    def __init__(self, session: requests.Session, base_url: str = "https://dashboard.cpolar.com"):
        """
        Initialize tunnel manager with authenticated session
        
        Args:
            session: Authenticated requests.Session from CpolarAuth
            base_url: Base URL for cpolar dashboard
        """
        self.session = session
        self.base_url = base_url
        self.status_url = f"{base_url}/status"
        self.auth_url = f"{base_url}/auth"
    
    def get_tunnel_info(self) -> TunnelInfo:
        """
        Get tunnel information from cpolar status page
        
        Returns:
            TunnelInfo object containing tunnel details
        """
        try:
            console.print("[dim]Fetching tunnel information...[/dim]")
            
            # Get status page
            response = self.session.get(self.status_url, timeout=10)
            response.raise_for_status()
            
            # Check if we're still authenticated
            if '/login' in response.url:
                raise TunnelError(_('error.session_expired'))
            
            # Parse tunnel information
            tunnel_url = self._parse_tunnel_url(response.text)
            
            # Extract hostname and port
            hostname, port = self._extract_hostname_and_port(tunnel_url)
            
            # Create TunnelInfo object
            tunnel_info = TunnelInfo(
                url=tunnel_url,
                hostname=hostname,
                port=port,
                name="ssh"
            )
            
            console.print(f"[green]✅ Found tunnel: {tunnel_url}[/green]")
            logger.info(f"Tunnel info: {tunnel_info}")
            
            return tunnel_info
            
        except requests.RequestException as e:
            logger.error(f"Network error while fetching tunnel info: {e}")
            raise NetworkError(_('error.network', error=e))
        except TunnelError:
            raise
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error getting tunnel info: {e}")
            raise TunnelError(_('error.tunnel', error=e))
    
    def _parse_tunnel_url(self, html_content: str) -> str:
        """
        Parse tunnel URL from status page HTML
        
        Args:
            html_content: HTML content of status page
            
        Returns:
            Tunnel URL (e.g., "tcp://x.tcp.vip.cpolar.cn:12345")

        soup = BeautifulSoup(html_content, 'html.parser')

                return tunnel_url

        tcp_pattern = re.compile(r'tcp://[a-zA-Z0-9\.\-]+:\d+')
        matches = tcp_pattern.findall(html_content)
        if matches:

            return tunnel_url
        
        # Method 3: Look in table cells
        for td in soup.find_all('td'):
            text = td.text.strip()
            if text.startswith('tcp://'):
                logger.debug(f"Found tunnel URL in table cell: {text}")
                return text
        
        # Method 4: Look for specific class or id that might contain tunnel info
        # This depends on cpolar's current HTML structure
        tunnel_containers = soup.find_all(['div', 'span', 'p'], string=tcp_pattern)
        if tunnel_containers:
            for container in tunnel_containers:
                match = tcp_pattern.search(container.text)
                if match:
                    tunnel_url = match.group(0)
                    logger.debug(f"Found tunnel URL in container: {tunnel_url}")

        # Save page content for debugging
        with open("tunnel_status_debug.html", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
            f.write(html_content)
        
        logger.error("Could not find tunnel URL in status page")
        raise TunnelError(_('tunnel.not_found'))
    
    def _extract_hostname_and_port(self, tunnel_url: str) -> Tuple[str, int]:
        """
        Extract hostname and port from tunnel URL
        
        Args:
            tunnel_url: Full tunnel URL (e.g., "tcp://x.tcp.vip.cpolar.cn:12345")
            
        Returns:
            Tuple of (hostname, port)
        """
        # Pattern for tcp://hostname:port
        pattern = r'^tcp://([a-zA-Z0-9\.\-]+):(\d+)$'
        match = re.match(pattern, tunnel_url)
        
        if not match:
            # Try without tcp:// prefix
            pattern = r'^([a-zA-Z0-9\.\-]+):(\d+)$'
            match = re.match(pattern, tunnel_url)
        
        if match:
            hostname = match.group(1)
            port = int(match.group(2))
            logger.debug(f"Extracted hostname={hostname}, port={port}")
            return hostname, port
        else:
            logger.error(f"Failed to parse tunnel URL: {tunnel_url}")
            raise TunnelError(_('error.tunnel_url_invalid', url=tunnel_url))
    
    def get_auth_token(self) -> Optional[str]:
        """
        Get authentication token from cpolar auth page
        
        Returns:
            Auth token string or None if not found
        """
        try:
            response = self.session.get(self.auth_url, timeout=10)
            response.raise_for_status()
            
            soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
            
            # Look for authtoken input field
            authtoken_input = soup.find("input", {"id": "authtoken"})
            if authtoken_input:
                token = authtoken_input.get("value", "").strip()
                if token:
                    logger.debug("Successfully obtained auth token")
                    return token
            
            # Alternative: look for token in different places
            # Sometimes it might be in a code block or pre tag
            for element in soup.find_all(['code', 'pre']):
                text = element.text.strip()
                if text.startswith('authtoken:') or 'authtoken' in text:
                    # Extract token from text
                    token_match = re.search(r'authtoken:\s*([a-zA-Z0-9_\-]+)', text)
                    if token_match:
                        token = token_match.group(1)
                        logger.debug("Found auth token in code block")
                        return token
            
            logger.warning("Auth token not found on auth page")
            return None
            
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error getting auth token: {e}")
            return None
    
    def get_all_tunnels(self) -> Dict[str, TunnelInfo]:
        """
        Get all tunnel information (for future multi-tunnel support)
        
        Returns:
            Dictionary of tunnel name -> TunnelInfo
        """
        # For now, just return single SSH tunnel
        # Future implementation could parse multiple tunnels
        tunnel_info = self.get_tunnel_info()
        return {tunnel_info.name: tunnel_info}
    
    def verify_tunnel_active(self, tunnel_info: TunnelInfo) -> bool:
        """
        Verify that a tunnel is active
        
        Args:
            tunnel_info: TunnelInfo object to verify
            
        Returns:
            True if tunnel is active, False otherwise

            # Re-fetch status page
            response = self.session.get(self.status_url, timeout=10)
            response.raise_for_status()
            
            # Check if tunnel URL is still present
            return tunnel_info.url in response.text
            
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error(f"Error verifying tunnel: {e}")

SSH management module for Cpolar Connect
"""

import os
import stat
import subprocess
import logging
from pathlib import Path
from typing import Optional, Tuple, List
import paramiko
from rich.console import Console
from rich.prompt import Prompt
from getpass import getpass

from .config import CpolarConfig
from .tunnel import TunnelInfo
from .exceptions import SSHError
from .i18n import _

console = Console()
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


class SSHManager:
    """Manage SSH keys and connections"""
    
    def __init__(self, config: CpolarConfig):
        """
        Initialize SSH manager with configuration
        
        Args:
            config: CpolarConfig object
        """
        self.config = config
        self.private_key_path = Path(os.path.expanduser(config.ssh_key_path))
        self.public_key_path = Path(str(self.private_key_path) + ".pub")
        self.ssh_dir = self.private_key_path.parent
        self.ssh_config_path = Path.home() / ".ssh" / "config"
        self.host_alias = config.ssh_host_alias
        self.server_user = config.server_user
        self.key_size = config.ssh_key_size
    
    def ensure_ssh_directory(self) -> None:
        """Ensure .ssh directory exists with correct permissions"""
        if not self.ssh_dir.exists():
            try:
                self.ssh_dir.mkdir(parents=True, mode=0o700, exist_ok=True)
                logger.info(f"Created SSH directory: {self.ssh_dir}")
            except Exception as e:
                logger.error(f"Failed to create SSH directory: {e}")
                raise SSHError(_('error.ssh_dir_failed', error=e))
    
    def generate_ssh_key(self, force: bool = False) -> bool:
        """
        Generate SSH key pair if not exists
        
        Args:
            force: Force regeneration even if key exists
            
        Returns:

class I18n:
    """Internationalization manager"""
    
    def __init__(self, language: Optional[Language] = None):
        """
        Initialize i18n with specified language
        
        Args:
            language: Language to use, auto-detect if None
        """
        if language is None:
            language = self._detect_language()
        
        self.language = language
        self.messages = self._get_messages(language)
    
    def _detect_language(self) -> Language:
        """
        Auto-detect language from environment
        
        Priority:
        1. CPOLAR_LANG environment variable
        2. LANG environment variable
        3. Default to Chinese
        """
        # Check CPOLAR_LANG first
        cpolar_lang = os.environ.get('CPOLAR_LANG', '').lower()
        if cpolar_lang in ['en', 'english']:
            return Language.EN
        elif cpolar_lang in ['zh', 'chinese', 'cn']:
            return Language.ZH
        
        # Check system LANG
        system_lang = os.environ.get('LANG', '').lower()
        if 'zh' in system_lang or 'cn' in system_lang:
            return Language.ZH
        elif 'en' in system_lang:
            return Language.EN
        
        # Default to Chinese for Chinese users
        return Language.ZH
    
    def _get_messages(self, language: Language) -> Dict[str, str]:
        """Get messages for specified language"""
        if language == Language.EN:
            return Messages.EN
        elif language == Language.ZH:
            return Messages.ZH
        else:
            return Messages.ZH  # Default
    
    def get(self, message_key: str, **kwargs) -> str:
        """
        Get translated message
        
        Args:
            message_key: Message key (e.g., 'auth.login_success')
            **kwargs: Format parameters
            
        Returns:
            Translated and formatted message
        """
        message = self.messages.get(message_key, message_key)
        
        # Format message with parameters
        if kwargs:
            try:
                message = message.format(**kwargs)
            except KeyError as e:
                # If formatting fails, return message with error indication
                message = f"{message} [Format error: {e}]"
        
        return message
    
    def set_language(self, language: Language) -> None:
        """
        Change language at runtime
        
        Args:
            language: New language to use
        """
        self.language = language
        self.messages = self._get_messages(language)
    
    @classmethod
    def load_from_config(cls, config_path: Optional[Path] = None) -> 'I18n':
        """
        Load language preference from config file
        
        Args:
            config_path: Path to config file
            
        Returns:
            I18n instance with configured language
        """
        if config_path is None:
            config_path = Path.home() / ".cpolar_connect" / "config.json"
        
        language = None
        if config_path.exists():
            try:
                with open(config_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
                    config = json.load(f)
                    lang_str = config.get('language', '').lower()
                    if lang_str in ['en', 'english']:
                        language = Language.EN
                    elif lang_str in ['zh', 'chinese', 'cn']:
                        language = Language.ZH
            except Exception:
                pass
        
        return cls(language)


# Global i18n instance
_i18n: Optional[I18n] = None


def get_i18n() -> I18n:
    """Get or create global i18n instance"""
    global _i18n
    if _i18n is None:
        _i18n = I18n.load_from_config()
    return _i18n


def set_language(language: Language) -> None:
    """Set global language"""
    i18n = get_i18n()
    i18n.set_language(language)


def _(message_key: str, **kwargs) -> str:
    """
    Shortcut for getting translated message
    
    Usage:
        from cpolar_connect.i18n import _
        print(_('auth.login_success'))
        print(_('auth.logging_in', username='user@example.com'))
    """
    i18n = get_i18n()
    return i18n.get(message_key, **kwargs)","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

payload.text:
**Analyzing `ssh.py` functionality**

It seems that the placeholder "#ZgotmplZ" from Go's text/template signifies an invalid string when using `|safeURL`, but I’m not entirely sure. The code searches for the 'tcp://' pattern, which makes sense.

The script uses paramiko for generating keys and handling remote commands instead of SFTP, which is acceptable. However, there are security risks with disabling host key verification, which compromises safety for the sake of convenience. 

I noticed a mismatch in logging: there’s no global configuration, and the log path mentioned doesn’t actually record any output. That's a significant design oversight!

**Examining configuration and logging issues**

I noticed that the CPOLAR_LOG_LEVEL environment variable isn't being read to set logging. In the Config.display function, they check the keyring backend, which returns None to prevent user prompting — that’s a smart approach.

The CLI's default action connects without referencing `config.toml` but does fetch the config file from the home directory, which is good. However, unit tests are lacking, and while pytest config is present, there are no actual tests — that's a significant design gap. 

Additionally, there are potential concurrency issues on Windows regarding `ssh` command building. The use of hard-coded `base_url` in the config, however, seems appropriate, as does the logging functionality.

**Reviewing internationalization and logging configuration**

I see that the `_('...')` function is used widely, which is good. There are functions like `get_i18n` and `set_language`, but it’s unclear why the CLI uses `_` before setting the language. The default language is set to ZH, which is nice.

The `ConfigManager.get_password` pulls from the environment variable before the keyring—an effective choice. However, I'm unsure how logging is configured; without proper setup, debug logs won’t appear. 

It's interesting that they use a real-time spinner for status but call `getpass` inside it. There might be a potential issue since the spinner isn't active at that time!

**Evaluating logout and internationalization issues**

It seems like they're doing a clean logout check by verifying if 'auth' exists in the local scope, which is good since 'auth' is only set within a try block. 

However, I noticed that the i18n messages may be incomplete. The `i18n.py` file shows a truncated line: "error.ssh_upload_failed\": \"F." When I look further, the rest of the Chinese dictionary appears, but the English dictionary might be cut off too. I think it would be best to open the entire file to ensure there are no missing strings.

payload.text:
**Evaluating code issues**

I'm noticing that the status page is dynamic and may require certain tokens after authentication. The code seems to obtain those tokens, which is good.

Now, I need to think about Windows support. It looks like the code uses `which` to check commands, but that isn't available on Windows—there, `where` is used instead. This could cause it to fail, and it seems like they overlooked this issue. They need to catch the exception for a different path.

**Identifying cross-platform issues**

The README mentions some uncertainty with Windows, but I can use `shutil.which` for a cross-platform solution. There's another cross-platform concern regarding path expansions; `/.ssh` works on POSIX, while on Windows, Paramiko adapts those paths, which is good to know.

I see another note about `config.set`, where host aliases and SSH key paths might be patterns, which is helpful. However, the code displays 'Authenticating...' in the CLI without using i18n for those strings, although keys for i18n exist and could be unified. Lastly, the package version in the CLI matches what's in pyproject.

**Clarifying version inconsistencies and methods**

I see the `__init__` version 0.0.1 is inconsistent. There are potential network restrictions with reading the remote page at 'dashboard.cpolar.com', which is useful to note.

The `TunnelManager.get_auth_token` method tries to parse the page to retrieve the auth token, but it isn't actually used in the code. It could be removed, or kept for future use. The doctor functionality doesn't seem to utilize it either; it checks the 'cpolar auth' status through a session instead, suggesting the 'auth' method may not be necessary.

As for the manager classes, `CpolarAuth` uses `requests.Session` to obtain the CSRF token and check login success. Meanwhile, `TunnelManager` leverages the session to parse the status page, and `SSHManager` employs paramiko for generating keys and `subprocess.run` for interactive SSH connections.

**Compiling findings and review**

I see some duplication in testing the connection with Paramiko and then using 'ssh' to simplify interactions, which makes sense. However, there's no global error handling in the CLI for exceptions raised by 'update_ssh_config', though they do catch errors in the connection phase.

The `dist` folder includes prebuilt wheels and tar for release, which is great, but the `CLAUDE.md` file and the `.codex` directory are irrelevant. The `LICENSE` exists, but the `__author__` placeholder doesn't match; it's not critical, though.

The user asked about "检查目前项目的设计" without further details, so I plan to keep the review concise yet complete. I'll organize it into sections like '总体结构', '核心流程', '配置与存储', 'CLI 命令', '国际化', '日志与可观测性', '安全性', '跨平台', '测试与发布', '风险点', and '优化建议', ensuring I use bullet lists with bold keywords.

**Updating and composing the plan review**

We should update our plan now that we've completed the inventory step and read the README. I can mark "Read README and docs" and "Identify entry points and modules" as completed. We can also produce data flow and dependencies, assess build/config/scripts, and summarize risks and improvements.

However, the instructions state there should always be one step in progress until everything is done. I see some confusion about whether I need a preamble message for the update_plan call. Since it’s a tool call, I’ll add a brief preamble: "结构梳理完成；我将更新计划为完成。" 

Now, I’ll go ahead and call update_plan with all steps marked as completed. The final message should summarize the design review in Chinese, with concise bullet points:

- **总体结构:** Python CLI packaging with subpackages like config, auth, tunnel, and ssh.
- **核心流程:** Steps include login, getting the tunnel, testing SSH, asking for a password, uploading keys, updating SSH config, and connecting.
- **数据流与依赖:** The flow uses requests, BeautifulSoup, paramiko, keyring, pydantic, and rich.
- **配置:** Configuration is stored in `/.cpolar_connect/config.json`, accessed using Pydantic models.
- **诊断:** The doctor checks the config existence, network connectivity, and password presence.

I’ll also mention that the current version is 0.1.0 according to pyproject settings, while the CLI version matches, although there's a mismatch with __init__. Lastly, I’d note that the latest release date according to CHANGELOG is January 19, 2025.

payload.text:
**Reviewing configuration updates**

I need to fix the "cpolarConnect doctor" not requiring an OS-specific 'which'. Then, there's the risk of using 'StrictHostKeyChecking no' across sessions, so proposing a system to ask once and store known_hosts would be better. I also want to add a 'retry/backoff' on HTTP and a "dry-run" mode for non-interactive tasks. 

Now, regarding "config.toml," it seems it's in the root but not used by the Python package, and it could contain sensitive information, which makes reading it tricky.

**Planning design review presentation**

The file is in the repo, but it has restricted permissions, making me hesitant to open it since it might contain secrets. While there are no direct instructions against opening it, I want to avoid any issues related to sensitive information. Luckily, for the design review, we don't need to open that file. I’ll check the `.codex` folder later if needed. 

For the design review, I’ll structure it with a summary, directory structure, data flow, config design, error handling, security, cross-platform considerations, packaging, release, and then highlight any gaps and suggestions for actionable next steps.

**Updating testing plan**

I noticed the tests directory is empty, so I propose adding tests for better coverage. This includes unit tests for config validation, an integration test for HTML parsing using a sample status page, and end-to-end tests with mocked servers, although we won't implement those right now. 

Now, as we wrap things up, I need to update the overall plan and mark it as completed, providing a brief explanation for clarity. Let’s get that done!

I need to fix the "cpolarConnect doctor" not requiring an OS-specific 'which'. Then, there's the risk of using 'StrictHostKeyChecking no' across sessions, so proposing a system to ask once and store known_hosts would be better. I also want to add a 'retry/backoff' on HTTP and a "dry-run" mode for non-interactive tasks. 

Now, regarding "config.toml," it seems it's in the root but not used by the Python package, and it could contain sensitive information, which makes reading it tricky.

**Planning design review presentation**

The file is in the repo, but it has restricted permissions, making me hesitant to open it since it might contain secrets. While there are no direct instructions against opening it, I want to avoid any issues related to sensitive information. Luckily, for the design review, we don't need to open that file. I’ll check the `.codex` folder later if needed. 

For the design review, I’ll structure it with a summary, directory structure, data flow, config design, error handling, security, cross-platform considerations, packaging, release, and then highlight any gaps and suggestions for actionable next steps.

**Updating testing plan**

Now, as we wrap things up, I need to update the overall plan and mark it as completed, providing a brief explanation for clarity. Let’s get that done!

payload.message:
**总体结论**
- 项目是一个用 Python 实现的命令行工具，通过登录 cpolar 控制台抓取隧道地址，再自动完成 SSH 免密、端口转发与连接。整体分层清晰（配置/认证/隧道/SSH/诊断/i18n），可维护性较好，用户文档与包装配置完备。
- 主要改进点：日志与可观测性缺失、跨平台细节（Windows）不足、版本与元数据不一致、对网页结构变化的韧性仍依赖爬取策略。

**目录与模块**
- 核心包：`src/cpolar_connect/`
  - `cli.py`: Click CLI 入口，默认执行“登录 → 获取隧道 → 测 SSH →（必要时）上传公钥 → 写入 ~/.ssh/config → 连接”。
  - `config.py`: 使用 Pydantic 定义配置模型与读写逻辑，支持 dot-notation 的 `get/set`，密码优先读 `CPOLAR_PASSWORD`，否则用 `keyring`。
  - `auth.py`: `requests + BeautifulSoup` 登录 cpolar（获取 CSRF → 提交表单 → 跟随跳转 → 成功特征判断）。
  - `tunnel.py`: 解析 `/status` 页面中的 `tcp://host:port`，多策略兜底。
  - `ssh.py`: 用 Paramiko 生成/检测密钥与免密可用性；实际连接用系统 `ssh`（便于交互和端口转发）。
  - `doctor.py`: 诊断（配置/网络/认证/隧道/SSH/命令存在性）并给出建议。
  - `i18n.py`: 简易 i18n（中/英），支持从配置及环境变量检测。
- 包装与分发：`pyproject.toml` 配好 `cpolar-connect` 入口；`dist/` 有 0.1.0 及 dev 构件；`MANIFEST.in` 完整打包源与文档。
- 文档：中英 README 与服务器配置指南齐全。CHANGELOG 最近版本为 0.1.0（2025-01-19）。

**核心流程（数据/控制流）**
- 配置加载：`~/.cpolar_connect/config.json` → 校验（端口范围、日志级别、语言）→ 读取密码（env > keyring）。
- 认证：`GET /login` 抓 CSRF → `POST /login` → 跳转/正文特征判断是否登录成功。
- 隧道解析：`GET /status` → 优先解析特定节点，再用正则兜底匹配 `tcp://...:port`。
- SSH：Paramiko 先测免密 → 不通则用密码登录上传公钥 → 更新 `~/.ssh/config` → 调用系统 `ssh` 建连并 `-L` 转发配置端口。
- 诊断：逐项检查并展示表格与修复建议。

**优点**
- 关注用户体验：首次连接自动生成密钥、上传公钥、写入 SSH 别名与本地转发，一步到位。
- i18n 与 CLI 提示完善；`doctor` 提供可操作的自检与建议。
- 配置与密码管理比较稳妥（优先环境变量，减少 macOS 钥匙串弹窗）。
- 解析隧道多策略兜底，减少页面改动的脆弱性。

**主要风险与不足**
- 安全性：
  - `StrictHostKeyChecking no` 与 `UserKnownHostsFile /dev/null` 永久禁用主机校验，存在中间人风险。
  - 首次上传公钥走密码登录，若密码被误配或弱密码，可能引发暴露风险（可接受但需提醒）。
- 稳定性：
  - 依赖抓取 cpolar 网页（`/login`、`/status`）结构，一旦改版，登录与解析会失效；虽有多策略，但仍属脆弱面。
- 观测性：
  - 虽创建了日志目录，但未见集中化日志配置（无 RotatingFileHandler/level 统一控制）。README 中的日志路径与实际落盘不一致。
- 跨平台：
  - `doctor.check_command` 使用外部命令 `which`，Windows 上不可用（应使用 `shutil.which`）。
  - CLI 与 SSH 参数在 Windows 原生终端环境可用性存疑（README 也标注 Windows 待定）。
- 体验一致性：
  - `cli.py` 中部分提示未走 i18n（如 “Authenticating with cpolar...” 等临时字符串），语言切换后提示不统一。
- 元数据一致性：
  - 版本与作者信息不一致：`pyproject.toml` 为 `0.1.0`；`cli.py` 装饰器也是 `0.1.0`，但 `__init__.py` 为 `0.0.1` 且作者占位。
- 测试空缺：
  - `tests/` 为空；缺少对 HTML 解析、登录成功/失败路径、配置 `set/get` 与 SSH 关键路径的单测/集成测试。
- 小问题：
  - 失败解析时写 `tunnel_status_debug.html` 到工作目录，建议写入日志目录并带时间戳。
  - `config.edit` 默认 `nano`，在 Windows/macOS 未必存在；可按平台回退到 `notepad`/`open -e` 或尊重 `$EDITOR`。

**建议（按优先级）**
- 安全与稳定
  - 可选开启主机密钥校验：新增 `ssh.strict_host_key_checking` 配置（默认 on），首次连接可提示用户接受并写入 `known_hosts`。
  - 为 HTTP 请求加上重试与退避（`urllib3.Retry` 或手写重试），登录与抓取更稳健；对解析失败提供更明确的诊断输出。
- 可观测性
  - 在 `cli.py` 入口集中配置 `logging`：依据配置或 `CPOLAR_LOG_LEVEL` 输出到 `~/.cpolar_connect/logs/cpolar.log`，使用 `RotatingFileHandler`，并在 DEBUG 模式记录关键 URL、状态码与解析路径（注意脱敏）。
  - 将 `tunnel_status_debug.html` 与网络故障快照写入日志目录，文件名带时间戳。
- 跨平台
  - 用 `shutil.which('ssh')` 替换外部 `which`，或在 Windows 使用 `where`；必要时明确 Windows 依赖（例如 Git for Windows 的 `ssh`）。
  - `config.edit` 按平台选择编辑器：优先 `$EDITOR`，macOS 回退 `open -e`，Windows 回退 `notepad`。
- 体验与一致性
  - 统一 i18n：将 `cli.py` 中状态提示改为 `i18n` 字典键（如 `auth.csrf_token`、`tunnel.fetching`）。
  - 版本与作者信息统一：`__init__.py` 的 `__version__` 与作者与 `pyproject.toml` 对齐；或仅从包元数据读取。
- 功能增强（可选）
  - 新增 `cpolar-connect status`：只显示当前隧道与 SSH 配置，不执行连接。
  - 新增 `--dry-run`：执行到“写 SSH 配置”前停止，便于自动化脚本。
  - 支持多隧道/多主机配置（当前已留 `get_all_tunnels` 钩子）。
- 测试
  - 对 `auth/tunnel` 引入基于 `responses`/`pytest` 的 HTTP 伪造，覆盖：正常登录、CSRF 缺失、重定向失败、不同 HTML 结构解析路径。
  - `config.set` 的端口解析、布尔/整型校验的单元测试。
  - `ssh.SSHManager` 关键路径以 mock `paramiko` 与 `subprocess.run` 做行为断言。
- 文档
  - 在 README“安全性”章节提示主机密钥校验的开关与意义；在 Windows 章节补充依赖与已知限制。

如需，我可以：
- 先做“版本统一 + i18n 统一 + Windows ‘which’ 修复 + 日志落盘”的小改动与最小单元测试套件；
- 或者先补一个 `status` 子命令，便于用户在不连接的情况下查看当前状态。需要我直接按上述优先级提交补丁吗？

payload.text:
**Clarifying tool usage**

I'm figuring out that the apply_patch tool is separate from functions.shell. The earlier instructions said to use the apply_patch tool for file edits. I see that there's a tools list showing 'apply_patch' as separate from the functions namespace. It seems like the correct way to invoke it is through "shell apply_patch," even if earlier guidelines mentioned using it differently. I'll make sure to follow the instructions for invoking apply_patch correctly.

**Implementing version updates**

I see that we need to unify version and author info across files. Right now, __init__.py shows version "0.0.1" and has placeholders for the author, while pyproject has "0.1.0" and the author as Hoper_J. Since we have distributions for 0.1.0, I’ll update __init__.py to match this version and author info, using __author__ and __email__. I’m considering making it a single source of truth with importlib.metadata for version retrieval, but for now, I’ll just update __init__.py and consider updating cli.py to pull the version dynamically instead of using hard-coded strings.

**Unifying i18n in cli.py**

I’ve noticed that some strings in cli.py are hard-coded in English and need to be updated for internationalization (i18n). For instance, the string "Authenticating with cpolar..." is currently a literal in console.status and should be replaced with _('auth.csrf_token'). I need to search for other hard-coded strings, like "Fetching tunnel information...", changing it to _('tunnel.fetching'). There’s also "Testing SSH connection...," which isn’t defined in i18n — I might reuse 'ssh.connecting' for now or add a new key 'ssh.testing_connection'. Adding new keys can streamline this process.

**Enhancing i18n for prompts and messages**

I'm looking to add both English and Chinese (ZH) entries to our i18n dictionaries. The prompt "Enter password for {config.server_user}@{tunnel_info.hostname}:" needs a new key, possibly 'ssh.password_prompt,' but since we already have 'ssh.need_password_for_key_upload,' I'm considering leaving it as is to minimize changes. For the "Auto-connect after update?" prompt, I want to create new i18n keys like 'cli.auto_connect' and 'cli.basic_configuration.' Also, for the message "Configuration saved to: {path}," I'll add 'cli.config_saved_path' with translations, or I may stick with the original English wording to maintain clarity.

**Implementing various updates and features**

I’m planning to add a new key 'cli.config_saved_path' and review other untranslated strings like "Password Status" and "Config Dir," but I might leave them as is for now. The CLI command for language setting is hard-coded, so I won't change it either. For logging, I need to implement centralized logging and avoid issues with default configs if one doesn't exist. I'll create a helper function for logging setup and ensure we handle duplicates properly. Additionally, I'll implement a 'status' command to fetch and display tunnel info. I'll adjust everything to maintain minimal changes while improving overall functionality.

**Planning minimal updates and improvements**

I'm focusing on minimal tests for configuration settings like 'server.ports' and handling issues regarding 'server.auto_connect'. To avoid writing to the actual home directory during tests, I can monkeypatch the `Path.home()` method. I'll create a test file to verify set/get functions and check file existence. 

I'll detect platform-specific editors in `config.edit` and update the logging setup to include an environment variable for log levels. Lastly, I'll work on adding a status command to show relevant information. We’ll implement these updates in a structured sequence.

Since we have distributions for 0.1.0, I’ll update __init__.py to match this version and author info, using __author__ and __email__. I’m considering making it a single source of truth with importlib.metadata for version retrieval, but for now, I’ll just update __init__.py and consider updating cli.py to pull the version dynamically instead of using hard-coded strings.

**Unifying i18n in cli.py**

I’ve noticed that some strings in cli.py are hard-coded in English and need to be updated for internationalization (i18n). For instance, the string "Authenticating with cpolar..." is currently a literal in console.status and should be replaced with _('auth.csrf_token'). I need to search for other hard-coded strings, like "Fetching tunnel information...", changing it to _('tunnel.fetching'). There’s also "Testing SSH connection...," which isn’t defined in i18n — I might reuse 'ssh.connecting' for now or add a new key 'ssh.testing_connection'. Adding new keys can streamline this process.

**Enhancing i18n for prompts and messages**

I'm looking to add both English and Chinese (ZH) entries to our i18n dictionaries. The prompt "Enter password for {config.server_user}@{tunnel_info.hostname}:" needs a new key, possibly 'ssh.password_prompt,' but since we already have 'ssh.need_password_for_key_upload,' I'm considering leaving it as is to minimize changes. For the "Auto-connect after update?" prompt, I want to create new i18n keys like 'cli.auto_connect' and 'cli.basic_configuration.' Also, for the message "Configuration saved to: {path}," I'll add 'cli.config_saved_path' with translations, or I may stick with the original English wording to maintain clarity.

**Implementing various updates and features**

I’m planning to add a new key 'cli.config_saved_path' and review other untranslated strings like "Password Status" and "Config Dir," but I might leave them as is for now. The CLI command for language setting is hard-coded, so I won't change it either. For logging, I need to implement centralized logging and avoid issues with default configs if one doesn't exist. I'll create a helper function for logging setup and ensure we handle duplicates properly. Additionally, I'll implement a 'status' command to fetch and display tunnel info. I'll adjust everything to maintain minimal changes while improving overall functionality.

**Planning minimal updates and improvements**

I'm focusing on minimal tests for configuration settings like 'server.ports' and handling issues regarding 'server.auto_connect'. To avoid writing to the actual home directory during tests, I can monkeypatch the `Path.home()` method. I'll create a test file to verify set/get functions and check file existence. 

I'll detect platform-specific editors in `config.edit` and update the logging setup to include an environment variable for log levels. Lastly, I'll work on adding a status command to show relevant information. We’ll implement these updates in a structured sequence.

payload.text:
**Implementing status command behavior**

I need to enhance the status command to account for scenarios where login fails or a password is missing. Right now, it's trying to log in even when the password is absent, which contradicts our intention to display local configuration info first. I should modify the command to show a local config table instead of attempting a login when authentication fails. I also need to figure out how to reference the last known tunnel since there's no persistence in the config.

**Updating status command for user experience**

I realize we need to change the implementation to inform users correctly about their authentication status. Instead of always trying to log in, I’ll adjust the status command to attempt login only if a password is available. If there’s no password, I'll display "Not logged in" and show local config info with notes like "cpolar: not authenticated" and "tunnel: unknown." I also need to update internationalization messages to reflect these statuses properly. Additionally, table formatting for "Local-only status (not authenticated)" will give clarity. I might also recommend using 'cpolar-connect doctor' for troubleshooting if the password isn't set.

**Adjusting status command exit behavior**

I need to modify the status command so it won't exit with a failure code when there's an exception. Instead, it should provide degraded information and return a success exit code. I’ll add a function that renders the status from the configuration and optional tunnel info, displaying a panel message for local-only status. If the password is absent, it will indicate that authentication is required. I also want the command to automatically handle degradation without raising an error code, ensuring a smooth user experience.

**Updating internationalization keys**

I’m considering keeping the exit code 1 only when the config can't be loaded at all. For internationalization, I need to add several new keys in both English and Chinese for the status updates. This includes messages for online and offline states, authentication issues, and network errors. I also want to revise the printed messages in the status command to reflect these changes. Finally, I'll implement a simple test to ensure that when a password is missing, the status function displays the table without exiting with an error.

**Implementing tests for CLI status**

I need to create tests for the CLI using `click.testing`'s `CliRunner`. This will help ensure that the status command correctly returns a code of 0 and includes the 'Offline' message, even without a network or password. To do this, I'll set up a temporary home directory for the config and invoke the status command while capturing the output. Additionally, I'll ensure that language defaults to English by setting `CPOLAR_LANG`. I'll also add checks to make sure the code skips the login attempt when no password is available. Lastly, I'll think about potential logging and edge cases to handle config status properly.

**Troubleshooting language settings**

I've noticed that the test failed because the output is in Chinese, even though I set CPOLAR_LANG=en. It seems like the language default in the config file is set to 'zh', and our test didn't specify a language. The issue arises because the load process prioritizes the config settings over the environment variable. Specifically, the config file saved will keep 'zh' as the default, which is why my attempt to set CPOLAR_LANG isn't working. I need to revisit how the loading process prioritizes language settings.

**Adjusting language settings in tests**

I see that get_i18n uses load_from_config, which defaults to 'zh', so I'll need to set 'language':'en' in the config for my test. payload.text:
**Analyzing the necessity of the doctor command**

I need to assess whether the “doctor” command is still necessary after introducing local-only status. I’ll compare the utility of both: the status command shows configuration and tunnels, while the doctor command performs checks and suggests diagnostic steps, checking things like network, key presence, and authentication. So, yes, the doctor command remains useful! I could suggest integrating its output with status or merging features for better function and simplicity.

**Reviewing the Doctor class functionality**

Right now, the Doctor class includes various checks like config, password, network connection to cpolar.com, authentication login, and tunnel presence. It also runs advanced checks such as ping, DNS resolution, local port status, firewall checks, and SSH service availability. I could suggest keeping the Doctor as a "guided repair" tool with suggestions for fixes, especially since it's integrated with i18n and documentation. I’d also recommend adjusting it for offline support, suggesting it when the status is offline. Plus, let's make the 'which' command cross-platform!

**Assessing Doctor improvements**

I have a few additional ideas for the Doctor feature, like adding options for "doctor --offline" or "doctor --login" as an optional parameter. The Doctor tool is complementary to status, where status shows "what is," but Doctor explains "why it's not working" and how to fix it. I suggest making Doctor a library that status can use for quick hints, or even adding a `--suggest` mode to status. We could also propose specific changes based on user needs, but I need to provide a clear answer about the Doctor's necessity.

**Evaluating the necessity of the Doctor command**

Considering the CLI style guidelines, my final answer should be concise and possibly organized in bullet points. I believe we should keep the Doctor command as it serves as a more comprehensive health check. Here are some key reasons: 

- It checks network, authentication, keys, and configuration.
- Provides actionable advice to users.
- Can be utilized in CI or support contexts.
- Allows for script integration via non-zero exit codes. 

Additionally, I suggest adding a hint on `status` that suggests running the Doctor for repair advice, even though the user mainly asked if Doctor is still necessary.

**Evaluating the necessity of the Doctor command**

我建议保留 Doctor 命令，以下是几个理由：

- 深度不同：status 告诉您现状，而 Doctor 解释为什么不行以及如何修复。
- 检查范围：Doctor 会检查网络、认证、隧道、SSH 密钥等，而 status 仅显示隧道和本地配置。
- 自动化：Doctor 的退出码可用于脚本和 CI。
- 用户支持：通过 Doctor 输出更容易反馈问题。

如果需要，我可以在 status 离线时添加提示：“提示：运行 doctor 获取修复建议”。这是一个有价值的集成！

payload.message:
保留很有必要。二者定位不同、互补而不是替代。

- 角色差异: status 是“当前状态快照”，doctor 是“故障定位器 + 修复建议”。
- 检查范围: doctor 会主动探测网络、cpolar 认证、隧道是否活跃、ssh 密钥/权限、ssh 命令可用性等；status 仅展示隧道与本地 SSH 配置（离线时给出原因）。
- 动作与信号: doctor 按检查结果给出可操作指引，并用非零退出码标记故障，便于脚本/CI 集成；status 通常零副作用、读信息为主。
- 支持协作: 让用户贴一份 doctor 输出，定位问题更快（比口述环境有效）。

可小改进（如需要我可顺手补上）：
- 在 status 处于“离线（仅本地）”时，附加一行提示“运行 cpolar-connect doctor 获取修复建议”。
- 给 doctor 增加 `--quick/--verbose/--offline`，按需深度与是否尝试登录。需要的话我现在就实现。

**Proposing unit test areas**

I need to respond to the user's question about where to add unit tests. They've changed the environment, meaning we can't make further writes. They're asking for recommendations, so I should suggest test areas like auth, tunnel, ssh, config, i18n, cli interactions, doctor, logging, editor fallback, and Windows detection. I can propose unit and integration tests with mocking while considering running constraints and the ephemeral environment. We should also refer to previous coverage stats to identify gaps in testing.

**Creating a test plan matrix**

I need to propose a test plan matrix that covers several modules. For the Auth module, I want to include login tests for success and failure scenarios, token retrieval, and behavior verification, such as fallback mechanisms and logout actions.

In the Tunnel module, I’ll check parsing of HTML fixtures, debug file paths, and the active tunnel function with mocked responses.

For the SSH module, I plan to include tests for key management, permission verification, connection handling, and ensuring the correct command builds without making an actual connection.

**Detailing the test plan for modules**

For the Config module, I'll focus on testing the mapping for all dot-notation keys, validating log levels, and ensuring proper errors are raised for invalid values. I'll also consider using monkeypatching for OS-specific fallbacks, testing password retrieval through the environment variable versus the keyring, and handling different boolean inputs while validating port strings.

In the CLI section, I'm going to verify argument parsing, integration with Click's CliRunner, and responses for different commands, including checks for errors.

Lastly, for the Doctor module, I’ll ensure functions like check_config and check_network handle exceptions appropriately.

**Verifying the code and modules**

I need to check the implementation of the `check_cpolar_auth` function, which calls `CpolarAuth` and should only attempt a login if the password is available. I’ll ensure that the error handling and result displays are correctly formatted, especially for showing recommendations.

For the i18n module, I'll verify language detection from environmental variables, formatting messages with placeholders, and ensuring the fallback works to zh by default. Lastly, for logging, I'll test that the log file is created in the specified path and that it rotates properly.

**Drafting a testing plan**

I need to create a plan for testing various modules while ensuring that a log file is created and logging levels are managed through environment variables. For edge cases, I’ll make sure `update_ssh_config` can handle existing entries appropriately.

I want to provide sample HTML fixtures in `tests/fixtures/` and include test utilities like context managers for mocking. Parametrization for ports and clear coverage goals are essential.

I'll also address OS-specific issues in tests and consider using environment variables to gate heavy tests. Finally, I plan to outline high-value test areas and provide code snippets where necessary, keeping everything concise yet thorough.

payload.message:
**优先补测点**
- **Auth/HTTP 解析**: 覆盖 CSRF 获取多分支（input/meta/缺失）、登录成功/失败（302 跳转、停留在 /login）、`is_authenticated` 的重定向与正文特征判断、`logout` 容错与异常映射。
- **Tunnel 解析**: 覆盖 4 条解析路径（目标 a 标签/正则匹配/表格单元/容器匹配）、无隧道报错、非法 URL 解析报错、`verify_tunnel_active` True/False、调试 HTML 写入日志目录。
- **SSH 流程**: 覆盖密钥生成/再生（.pub 丢失时再生）、权限设置失败容错、免密失败→密码上传公钥→再测成功链路、`update_ssh_config` 新增/替换 host block 与端口多条 `LocalForward`、`connect` 构建命令（含 `-L`/严格参数）与 `auto_connect=False` 提示路径。
- **Config 行为**: 所有 dot-notation 键的 `get/set`（类型规范化、错误分支）、端口字符串/列表/单值解析、布尔值多写法（true/false/yes/no/1/0/on/off）、`log_level` 合法性与大小写、语言校验、`edit()` 的平台回退与 `$EDITOR`、`get_password()/has_stored_password()` 的 env 优先与 keyring Mock。
- **CLI 命令**: `config get/set/show/path/clear-password/language` 输出与退出码、`status` 在线/离线（无密码/认证失败/网络失败）三路径、`--version` 与包版本一致性。
- **Doctor 诊断**: `check_config/password/network/cpolar_auth/tunnel/ssh_key/ssh_config/command` 的通过/告警/失败分支、`display_results()` 表格与建议文案、`run()` 非零返回规则。

**Mock 与夹具建议**
- **HTTP**: 用 `responses` 或 `requests-mock` stub `GET /login`、`POST /login`、`GET /status`、`GET /logout`；提供多版 HTML 夹具（放 `tests/fixtures/`）分别触发各解析分支与失败分支。
- **Paramiko**: `unittest.mock` 替换 `paramiko.SSHClient` 和 `RSAKey`，断言 `exec_command` 与写入 `authorized_keys` 的命令构造；替换 `subprocess.run` 断言 `ssh` 命令行拼接。
- **文件系统**: 用 `tmp_path` + `monkeypatch.setattr(Path, 'home', ...)` 隔离 `~`，验证密钥/配置/日志文件位置与内容；Windows 权限语义不同，权限断言在非 Windows 平台执行或放宽。
- **平台分支**: `platform.system()` 用 monkeypatch 驱动 `config.edit()` 的 `open -e`/`notepad`/`nano` 回退；`doctor.check_command` 使用 `shutil.which` 可 Mock 返回值。
- **i18n**: 通过 `CPOLAR_LANG`/`LANG` 覆盖语言探测、占位符格式化、`set_language()` 与 `_()` 缓存行为。

**建议的具体用例**
- **auth.login 成功**: `GET /login` 返回含 `<input name=csrf_token>`；`POST /login` 返回 302→`/status`；断言 `auth.is_authenticated()` True。
- **auth.login 失败**: `POST /login` 200 且正文含“登录失败/invalid credentials”；断言抛 `AuthenticationError`。
- **status 离线退化**: 无 `CPOLAR_PASSWORD` 与 keyring，`CliRunner` 执行 `status`，断言退出码 0、面板提示为“离线（仅本地）/Offline (local-only)”且表格字段存在。
- **tunnel 解析四分支**: 用四份不同结构的 `/status` HTML 断言解析到相同 `tcp://host:port`。
- **ssh.update_ssh_config**: 初次创建 vs 更新已存在 block；多端口转发全部存在；`StrictHostKeyChecking` 等参数存在。
- **doctor.run 汇总**: 通过 stub 让网络失败/密码缺失/ssh 命令缺失等，断言表格中状态为 WARN/FAIL，对应建议文案出现，`run()` 返回 False。

**覆盖率目标与顺序**
- 第一阶段（性价比最高）: `tunnel.py` 解析路径、`auth.py` 登录正反用例、`cli status` 三路径、`config.set/get` 输入规范化。目标总体覆盖 >60%。
- 第二阶段: `ssh.py`（Mock 后的关键路径）、`doctor.py` 的建议与退出码。目标总体覆盖 >75%。
- 第三阶段: 日志初始化（只断言日志文件创建、不测旋转）、i18n 探测分支。目标 ~80% 左右即可。

需要我起草这些测试的骨架文件（fixtures 和 mocks），并逐步补齐第一阶段用例吗？

- **文件系统**: 用 `tmp_path` + `monkeypatch.setattr(Path, 'home', ...)` 隔离 `~`，验证密钥/配置/日志文件位置与内容；Windows 权限语义不同，权限断言在非 Windows 平台执行或放宽。
- **平台分支**: `platform.system()` 用 monkeypatch 驱动 `config.edit()` 的 `open -e`/`notepad`/`nano` 回退；`doctor.check_command` 使用 `shutil.which` 可 Mock 返回值。
- **i18n**: 通过 `CPOLAR_LANG`/`LANG` 覆盖语言探测、占位符格式化、`set_language()` 与 `_()` 缓存行为。

**建议的具体用例**
- **auth.login 成功**: `GET /login` 返回含 `<input name=csrf_token>`；`POST /login` 返回 302→`/status`；断言 `auth.is_authenticated()` True。
- **auth.login 失败**: `POST /login` 200 且正文含“登录失败/invalid credentials”；断言抛 `AuthenticationError`。
- **status 离线退化**: 无 `CPOLAR_PASSWORD` 与 keyring，`CliRunner` 执行 `status`，断言退出码 0、面板提示为“离线（仅本地）/Offline (local-only)”且表格字段存在。
- **tunnel 解析四分支**: 用四份不同结构的 `/status` HTML 断言解析到相同 `tcp://host:port`。
- **ssh.update_ssh_config**: 初次创建 vs 更新已存在 block；多端口转发全部存在；`StrictHostKeyChecking` 等参数存在。
- **doctor.run 汇总**: 通过 stub 让网络失败/密码缺失/ssh 命令缺失等，断言表格中状态为 WARN/FAIL，对应建议文案出现，`run()` 返回 False。

**覆盖率目标与顺序**
- 第一阶段（性价比最高）: `tunnel.py` 解析路径、`auth.py` 登录正反用例、`cli status` 三路径、`config.set/get` 输入规范化。目标总体覆盖 >60%。
- 第二阶段: `ssh.py`（Mock 后的关键路径）、`doctor.py` 的建议与退出码。目标总体覆盖 >75%。
- 第三阶段: 日志初始化（只断言日志文件创建、不测旋转）、i18n 探测分支。目标 ~80% 左右即可。
